Dahlia, these men have been held at Guantanamo for years now.
So why's it taken so long for them to get to this point?
Two reasons, Madeleine.
One sort of legal, one tactical.
The legal reason is simply that the Bush administration made the decision, shortly after 9/11, they just were not going to use any existing legal system to try these folks.
So they opted out of the sort of civilian system that we're used to.
They opted out of the traditional military court-martial system and invented this whole new system of military commissions that's taken years and years and years to bang into shape.
More or less we've been bogged own in appeals and fits and starts, trips back and forth to the Supreme Court that have really precluded trials from happening at all.

The tactical reason is that the Bush administration made a strategic choice after 9/11, to go and interrogate these high value detainees - as they were called - for years and year, rather than try them.
That was a decision at the time that maybe made some sense.
They wanted to fend off any future attacks.
But what it meant was these folks were simply not ready to be tried until right now.
It's also worth saying it's recently come up that part of that interrogation may have involved waterboarding, which is certain to become a legal issue if the trials ever take place.
So these charges, how do they compare with the charges filed against the other detainees?
Well, certainly some of the detainees are facing very serious charges, Madeleine.
Canadian Omar Khadr, who would've been 15 at the time he was picked up in Afghanistan, is facing trial this spring for having thrown a grenade at an American soldier.
Salim Ahmed Hamdan, who is Osama bin Laden's driver, is facing serious charges this summer of delivering weapons for al-Qaida.
Of course, the difference now, is these folks are being tried for 9/11.
They're being tried for the actual conspiracy to take down the World Trade Center.
And so it's a whole different order of magnitude, even from attempted murder of an American soldier.
There's been a lot of talk, in the military and out of the military, in Congress - about closing down Guantanamo.
Will that talk continue as these proceedings continue or will that be put on hold?
Well, I think one of the reasons for the timing of these proceedings is to say, look, this is why we needed Guantanamo.
All that stuff you've been watching for the past couple of years - shucking and jiving about possibly creating some system - now we know why we need a system.
It's for this.
It's to try the 9/11 conspirators.
And it's going to be a way of not only saying this couldn't have done in any traditional court, but a way of binding future presidents.
Essentially saying, by the time these trials are up and running it may be years from now.
At which point President McCain or President Obama or President Clinton is going to have to stand by the system that the Bush administration devised.
If these men are found guilty and they are sentenced to death, there is no death chamber at Guantanamo, so how would the executions be carried out?
Well, again, Madeleine, it's important to emphasize I think this would be years away.

For what it's worth, military justice provides for death by lethal injection.

Dahlia, you mentioned the case of waterboarding, and just recently the United Nations has found that it is indeed a form of torture.
So what about all this evidence that was collected during these interrogation proceedings?
Would that be admitted and would that strenuously litigated on both sides?
Certainly the standards for what kind of evidence is admissible at Guantanamo is very fundamentally different from the standards of what's admissible at a criminal trial in a civilian system.
But I'm absolutely certain that one of the major issues that will be litigated by the defense attorneys is the fact that these folks were tortured, that the confessions were therefore unreliable.
To the extent that they implicated one another, it was unreliable.
So we're going to be hearing a lot more about that in the coming months and years.
